questions.question_text: What does MongoDB use for data storage?
questions.explanation: MongoDB uses a document-oriented database to store data, which allows for flexible and efficient storage of semi-structured data.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the $push operator in MongoDB?
questions.options_json: {"A": "To update a field with a new value", "B": "To add a new element to an array", "C": "To remove all occurrences of a value from an array", "D": "To sort an array"}
questions.explanation: The $push operator is used to add one or more elements to the end of an array. This can be useful for incrementally adding new data to a collection.

questions.question_text: What happens when you run the command `db.collection.drop()` in MongoDB?
questions.options_json: {"A": "It deletes all documents from the collection, but not the collection itself.", "B": "It drops the entire database, including all collections and data.", "C": "It removes the collection from the database, along with all its documents.", "D": "It creates a new collection with the same name as the original one."}
questions.explanation: The `drop()` command only deletes the documents in the specified collection, leaving the collection itself intact. This is useful for cleaning up data without affecting other collections or the database structure.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the $lookup aggregation operator in MongoDB?
questions.options_json: {"A": "To perform a left outer join with another collection", "B": "To merge two arrays into one", "C": "To filter documents based on a condition", "D": "To update multiple documents at once"}
questions.explanation: The $lookup operator is used to perform a left outer join with another collection, allowing you to retrieve data from related collections. This is useful for creating complex queries and aggregations.
